HIP 41: Governance By Token Lock V2 · Issue #302 · helium/HIP
Info Author(s): @tjain-mcc Start Date: September 17, 2021 Category: Governance Original HIP PR: #299 Tracking Issue: this Discord channel: #hip-41-governance-by-token-lock Status: Discussion Render...
08:42
## Info - Author(s): @tjain-mcc - Start Date: September 17, 2021 - Category: Governance - Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/299 - Tracking Issue: this - Discord channel: #hip-41-governance-by-token-lock - Status: Discussion ## Rendered view https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0041-governance-by-token-lock-v2.md ## Summary This proposal specifies a governance mechanism to enable modifications to chain variables (on-chain voting), and specifies an additional signaling mechanism for general purpose protocol improvements (off-chain voting). Note: This HIP has been submitted In direct response to "Rewrite HIP31 with Token Lock rather than Token Burn mechanism"
HIP draft: Governance by Token Lock V2 by Scottsigel · Pull Request...
Authors: @tjain-mcc (tushar) This proposal suggests a governance mechanism for on-chain voting for chain variables and protocol upgrades. rendered view: https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/21a732b58...
HIP/0041-governance-by-token-lock-v2.md at master · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
Rewrite HIP31 with Token Lock rather than Token Burn mechanism by t...
A rewrite of the existing HIP31. This proposal suggests on-chain governance voting for implementations of chain variables and protocol upgrades.
08:42
this was proposed as a replacement for #hip-31-governance-by-token-lock which i'll be closing if there's no objections
jpharris 10/27/2021 4:47 PM
So, to be clear, the only cost of voting is in liquidity? And the tokens are treated like validator-staked tokens aside from the locked timeframe? (edited)
Anthonyra 10/27/2021 6:23 PM
The way itâ€™s written makes it sound like it would be delegated stake to a validator? Iâ€™d be more inclined to have a wallet stake to itself for this purpose. The time the tokens are locked up plays into its weight which is good in my opinion.
18:26
I would also like to see an option to completely burn some HNT for a multiplier such as 100x? Therefore, 1 HNT at 5 months = 1 1 HNT at ~5 years = 50 1 HNT burnt = 100 So 1 HNT could out vote 100 staked at 5 months for example.
evan 10/27/2021 7:06 PM
my reading was that you stake to have voting rights
19:07
the multiplier was for earliness in the voting process
19:07
or was it for lockup time?
19:07
there have been a couple of variations thrown around, I'll read the final proposal tomorrow
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/27/2021 7:50 PM
This is actively bad for the most involved deployers of the network, that need liquidity to further fund their operations. You put them in the spot of either no liquidity to continue deployments, or having no say in the network they are helping build. Also, the assumption that this method prevents whales from controlling the voting is absurd. Whales are exactly the users that have the available resources to lock up a lot of tokens at the max multiplier with no impact. Voting via tokens is a rich person's game and shuts out anyone else.
2
Lee 10/28/2021 1:07 AM
Vote power should be linked to your involvement of the network imo. The more hotspots/validator you have deployed and the better they perform the more valuable your vote should be - to essentially reflect your engagement. Hnt amount should play a role too but be capped to avoid trading whales that have 0 interest in network.
Lee
Vote power should be linked to your involvement of the network imo. The more hotspots/validator you have deployed and the better they perform the more valuable your vote should be - to essentially reflect your engagement. Hnt amount should play a role too but be capped to avoid trading whales that have 0 interest in network.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped

1
Lee 10/28/2021 4:21 AM
There will always be people who can't/won't install a miner due various reasons, however, they may be contributing/involved in other ways - they, too, should be entitled to vote . By just installing a miner for the sake of voting, thereby potentially affecting the reward scaling negatively for everyone else, ain't doing any good for anybody. I believe that the ones who actually deploy them and regularly monitor and engage in improving the network should have a more valued vote than simply someone with merely tons of hnt. In the end, people who deploy miners and especially those who research and spend time and money to achieve good performing miners/validators (who are not gamers), are the ones who benefit the network. This itself is a win for the investors. Make the vote power dependant on how well you've contributed to the network. Or in other words, there should be a correlation between your vote power and your contribution - hnt amount alone is not a sufficient parameter for contribution. (edited)
jpharris 10/28/2021 4:37 AM
whales willing to lock up HNT for a long period of time do benefit the network, much as I hate the idea of buying the vote
evan 10/28/2021 7:27 AM
being able to buy tokens benefits stakeholders like network users
07:28
I am agnostic to this hip, but involving users is very important for the long term
07:34
also it is naive to directly link mining and good network behavior
oilbird 10/28/2021 7:38 AM
the same thing could be said about token holders tho
07:38
in fact i would think that "bad miners" make more tokens
capcom 10/28/2021 7:43 AM
Iâ€™d say in general the participants of these chats are fairly oblivious to how important token holders are and why they matter. frankly no one would be mining anything and none of you would be here if not for some of the largest token holders
1
oilbird 10/28/2021 7:49 AM
i agree, 99% of my helium networth is in hnt. i just want my tokens resistant by the least amount of friction between infrastructure and voice
Anthonyra 10/28/2021 7:51 AM
I do understand wanting to have a weight to every aspect of the network from hotspots, validators, DC, and HNT. To create something that takes into account all of these would be impressive. However, something that all of those individuals have in common to one degree or another is HNT. Just some food for thought, if there was an operator who owns 10 miners but continues to sell their HNT down to a balance of 0. What do you think they will do during hard times? That's the biggest question, I'm not concerned with those who join during the good times or stick around during them. I'm interested in those willing to stick around even through the bad. Be that willingly or forcibly... forcibly being staked. My opinion is that those kinds of individuals will jump ship and sell their miners on Ebay within days.
07:54
TL;DR I think it's a great start to a system that will grow using HNT with staked risk adding weight to the voting power. In the future there could be levers or knobs turned based on hotspot or validator counts maybe.. (edited)
capcom 10/28/2021 7:55 AM
Iâ€™d argue that large token holders are also more likely to make decisions that are long term beneficial to the network (arguably validators fit this category the most due to the lockup), whereas hotspot owners seem to in general be more concerned about rewards dilution. for example â€œ3 million more hotspots comingâ€ is amazing news to anyone thinking about the network long term, but hotspot owners tend to view this as â€œmy rewards are going to go down moreâ€
1
Anthonyra 10/28/2021 7:57 AM
However, I do think that a burn tier would be for those who want a louder vote but maybe don't have the HNT currently but are willing to risk it all to be heard more
oilbird 10/28/2021 8:01 AM
validators are a great way to use idle hnt, more validators brings more decentralization. i am just thinking that a lot of the helium token has already been mined due to halvings, and i don't understand why someone who buys a miner from last year is any more important than someone who buys a miner this year (given that both parties aren't selling tokens, and are mining the same amount of work with the same amount of correctness)
08:02
i definitely wouldn't suggest a proposal that disregards validators .. for reasons haha
Anthonyra 10/28/2021 8:03 AM
I think a stake should be needed maybe apply a multiplier to the vote power based on hotspot count? For example if you have 10 miners, 100 HNT x1 (for 5 months) x10 (for miners) wouldn't be too bad
capcom 10/28/2021 8:03 AM
hah, yeah thatâ€™s probably not smart
oilbird 10/28/2021 8:04 AM
the rewards block is such a beautiful symbiotic relationship
Tushar 10/28/2021 9:52 AM
I think the most important thing for a network governance system is that it is: (1) secure against sybil attacks - it is trivial to create new wallets so any proposal based on number of wallets voting for something fails the security test (2) long term aligned with the network - don't want to allow people to influence governance if their interests are not aligned for the long term success of the network (3) decentralized and permissionless - introducing KYC requirements for voting is antithetical to the ethos of the blockchain industry IMO (edited)
09:55
I did my best to meet those objectives with this HIP. I have reviewed many different governance models in crypto and am an active participant in several of them, I took all of those learnings to apply to this HIP
oilbird 10/28/2021 10:10 AM
I agree with your goals and I hope I didn't come off as discouraging in any way, on the contrary I am very thankful for your work in writing this HIP.
1
capcom
Iâ€™d argue that large token holders are also more likely to make decisions that are long term beneficial to the network (arguably validators fit this category the most due to the lockup), whereas hotspot owners seem to in general be more concerned about rewards dilution. for example â€œ3 million more hotspots comingâ€ is amazing news to anyone thinking about the network long term, but hotspot owners tend to view this as â€œmy rewards are going to go down moreâ€

By just installing a miner for the sake of voting, thereby potentially affecting the reward scaling negatively for everyone else, ain't doing any good for anybody. I believe that the ones who actually deploy them and regularly monitor and engage in improving the network should have a more valued vote than simply someone with merely tons of hnt. In the end, people who deploy miners and especially those who research and spend time and money to achieve good performing miners/validators (who are not gamers), are the ones who benefit the network. This itself is a win for the investors. Make the vote power dependant on how well you've contributed to the network. Or in other words, there should be a correlation between your vote power and your contribution - hnt amount alone is not a sufficient parameter for contribution. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/28/2021 12:40 PM
Exactly. Scale the vote based on HIP17 scaling
Tushar
I think the most important thing for a network governance system is that it is: (1) secure against sybil attacks - it is trivial to create new wallets so any proposal based on number of wallets voting for something fails the security test (2) long term aligned with the network - don't want to allow people to influence governance if their interests are not aligned for the long term success of the network (3) decentralized and permissionless - introducing KYC requirements for voting is antithetical to the ethos of the blockchain industry IMO (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/28/2021 1:01 PM
1. Yes, IF you base it only on wallets. You have to add a check for something they can't just create: Miners. 2. You can't gatekeep like that if you want to have a democratic system. You don't get to say "You can't vote because your views don't align with mine".
oilbird 10/28/2021 1:07 PM

13:11

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/28/2021 5:35 PM

17:37

evan
the idea that miners = votes but tokens don't = votes is very strange, given that you can just buy miners?
Fizzy 10/28/2021 7:41 PM
Harder to get hotspots than get token. Both will get better for accessibility... but I mention this again.. Hotspots = Providing Expansion of network and is out of pocket cost that you may never get back. Token = Just buy and holding a thing that may or may not have any value like any other Joe out there. Which one is more valuable to the network? (edited)
Fizzy 10/28/2021 7:53 PM
Given the current oracle, let's just use 25 for now.... 16x HNT = 1x Rakv2. If I voted with 16 HNT and had no hotspots, is that more valuable vs someone with 1 Hotspot and 1 HNT because they a lone wolf out somewhere?

## Info - Author(s): @tjain-mcc - Start Date: September 17, 2021 - Category: Governance - Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/299 - Tracking Issue: this - Discord channel: #hip-41-governance-by-token-lock - Status: Discussion ## Rendered view https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0041-governance-by-token-lock-v2.md ## Summary This proposal specifies a governance mechanism to enable modifications to chain variables (on-chain voting), and specifies an additional signaling mechanism for general purpose protocol improvements (off-chain voting). Note: This HIP has been submitted In direct response to "Rewrite HIP31 with Token Lock rather than Token Burn mechanism"
maco2035 ðŸ® 10/28/2021 10:55 PM

Vote power should be linked to your involvement of the network imo. The more hotspots/validator you have deployed and the better they perform the more valuable your vote should be - to essentially reflect your engagement. Hnt amount should play a role too but be capped to avoid trading whales that have 0 interest in network.
maco2035 ðŸ® 10/28/2021 10:58 PM

23:01

Peso die SchildkrÃ¶te ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª pinned a message to this channel. 10/29/2021 12:04 AM
Peso die SchildkrÃ¶te ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª pinned a message to this channel. 10/29/2021 12:04 AM
Fizzy 10/29/2021 12:21 AM
Well without the surge in hotspot deployment, network wouldn't really exist either. So maybe we come up with an equation that includes both variables.
KeithR 10/29/2021 3:29 AM
Since we will be having a computer counting the votes, there is no reason why we can't consider every role that is out there and weight them accordingly and thus have a rather complex equation that determines your voting power. Computers are really good at doing such equations. No reason that it can't be... one wallet + (HST * 0.nn --> less than 1 rate because they "have all of their other perks") + (HNT --> some diminishing returns function so that whales do have more voting power but not linear) * (--> time lock function with a diminishing returns function based on amount of HNT) + (hotspots --> some function that over rewards hotspots up to some point and then diminishing returns from there) + blah, blah, blah The overall voting power equation can easily reflect all of our values. Complex equations are just fine.
03:31
Sorry, I forgot to start with a kudos to this draft of the HIP. While there are three grammar errors, it is intellectually well written.
Lee 10/29/2021 3:54 AM
I like the idea of staked hnt amount over just hnt amount alone, +1, I also think there should be a weighted equation for the vote. some notes: Having heaps of hnt doesnt neccesarily mean you will vote for/understand which vote is best, long term. -hence the amount of staked hnt can be a nice weight parameter. Also, for instance, having loads of hotspots in the cellar + spoofing your location shouldnt give you a louder vote than say the regular Joe with two miners who is providing much better and real coverage. -in such case, the spoofer/hoarder would obviously abuse the system and vote for a solution that would benefit them and their gaming. (Not to mention, if they had the money to buy that many miners, they probably have the money to buy tons of hnt as well.) -hence hotspots count alone is not a valid parameter, one has to account for the hotspot's real benefit/performance to the network imo. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Miners are very hard to buy vs tokens. Also, it's not just miners = votes. It's installed miners that are actively benefiting the network = votes.
Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 4:51 AM
Elon, I understand where you're coming from, would love to see miners get a little extra power in addition to the HNT they've received, but we do also already have a metric for how useful a particular hotspot is to the network: how much HNT it has received. As I've said before, I understand HIP-20, though, might not be the ideal model for distributing governance weight, but it might also be the best we have or can do.
1
Lee
I like the idea of staked hnt amount over just hnt amount alone, +1, I also think there should be a weighted equation for the vote. some notes: Having heaps of hnt doesnt neccesarily mean you will vote for/understand which vote is best, long term. -hence the amount of staked hnt can be a nice weight parameter. Also, for instance, having loads of hotspots in the cellar + spoofing your location shouldnt give you a louder vote than say the regular Joe with two miners who is providing much better and real coverage. -in such case, the spoofer/hoarder would obviously abuse the system and vote for a solution that would benefit them and their gaming. (Not to mention, if they had the money to buy that many miners, they probably have the money to buy tons of hnt as well.) -hence hotspots count alone is not a valid parameter, one has to account for the hotspot's real benefit/performance to the network imo. (edited)

Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 5:01 AM
Maybe we can give the miners at least a little extra boost. Hotspots with a location set and recent PoC activity could have extra HNT voting weight = $50 / HNT oracle price per hotspot added to the wallet.
05:02
Since these hotspots have a $40 onboarding network fee and $10 location fee invested minimum
Angry Pickle Bear
Elon, I understand where you're coming from, would love to see miners get a little extra power in addition to the HNT they've received, but we do also already have a metric for how useful a particular hotspot is to the network: how much HNT it has received. As I've said before, I understand HIP-20, though, might not be the ideal model for distributing governance weight, but it might also be the best we have or can do.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:08 AM
Hnt is a poor metric in this case. I can just buy some hnt. I don't have to be useful to the network to get it.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Hnt is a poor metric in this case. I can just buy some hnt. I don't have to be useful to the network to get it.
Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 5:09 AM
Buying HNT is useful, though. HNT represents the "work" of a hotspot. If no one bought HNT, the network would be tiny.
Angry Pickle Bear
Buying HNT is useful, though. HNT represents the "work" of a hotspot. If no one bought HNT, the network would be tiny.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:10 AM
I can buy, vote, sell. No net usefulness to the network. (edited)
Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 5:10 AM

05:10

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:11 AM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
A token based voting system, stake, lock, burn, etc, is just voting for the rich.

Angry Pickle Bear

05:14

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:15 AM

Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 5:16 AM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:19 AM
I shouldn't have extra votes irl, just because I am older that some other voter, right? Older miners, that put in the same effort to the network were rewarded more than a more recent miner. Cheating miners also get more hnt than legit miners. Hnt is not the way to vote. Easily buying votes should not be allowed.
Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 5:21 AM
If that older owner didn't sell their HNT, then yeah, IMO, they are more valuable because they helped attract new miners
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/29/2021 5:21 AM

Angry Pickle Bear

KeithR
Since we will be having a computer counting the votes, there is no reason why we can't consider every role that is out there and weight them accordingly and thus have a rather complex equation that determines your voting power. Computers are really good at doing such equations. No reason that it can't be... one wallet + (HST * 0.nn --> less than 1 rate because they "have all of their other perks") + (HNT --> some diminishing returns function so that whales do have more voting power but not linear) * (--> time lock function with a diminishing returns function based on amount of HNT) + (hotspots --> some function that over rewards hotspots up to some point and then diminishing returns from there) + blah, blah, blah The overall voting power equation can easily reflect all of our values. Complex equations are just fine.
krby 10/29/2021 7:29 AM
Agree that we could make it as complex as we want, but there is a HUGE value in being able to explain the overall algorithm to people easily. People want to be able to sort of predict how the whole thing would work in various situations. (edited)

It'd be easier to motivate an operator to stake 1 - 100 HNT with the hotspot multiplier to allow them to continue to grow.

capcom 10/29/2021 3:11 PM
personally i'm confused by the extra steps here. the purpose of transmit scale, poc, etc is to optimize for HNT rewards. you already have a 'score' effectively for hotspot deployments in the form of HNT earned. it's not perfect because it diminishes over time. but using transmit scale is immediately broken because you can assert hotspots anywhere you want - do we really want fleet owners controlling governance this way? it seems backwards to me. also on your point about HST vs HNT - HST is just HNT on a vesting schedule. arguably HST holders are the most long term incentivized HNT holders by force (which is why we designed it this way). having a potentially uncorrelated asset like HGT is in no way the same thing

Multicoin Capital: The Helium Flywheel
Helium is a new crypto economic protocol that underpins a new business model deploying and managing wireless networks at about 100x lower cost than traditional top-down telecom business models.

Angry Pickle Bear 10/29/2021 6:51 PM
On the most basic level, HNT holders (which includes holders that are miners) want HNT to appreciate, miners want to earn more fiat value per day. The appreciation of HNT will ultimately have to come from high network usage and also drives the flywheel.
18:52
You can earn more fiat value per day if HNT appreciates, but it's less direct so there are situations for non holding miners to want things that are good for them, but not great for the network overall.
18:54
Like they are incentivized to vote for changes that make increasing the total number of miners on the network more difficult or block the introduction of new wireless protocols.

So itâ€™s a question of what would be fair. Should a fleet of 30 hotspots have the same voting power as one Validator or less? People who have HNT staked are in this project for the long term. KeithR 10/30/2021 3:19 PM
In my effort to make the equation as complex as possible so as to reflect all of our values...I propose the following simple equation to start the bidding. governance = HST holders + validators + loRaWAN hotspots + 5G hotspots + HNT holders + DC holders Am I missing any stakeholders? (edited)
1
Deleted User
Itâ€™s clear that youâ€™re against this proposal. Youâ€™ll also notice that no one is responding to you and thatâ€™s for a reason. Instead of belaboring this HIP whilst talking about a non existent token, write up a HIP.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 10/30/2021 4:34 PM
Your snarky reply in no way adds to the conversation.
KeithR 10/31/2021 1:03 AM
So if we have governance = HST holders + validators + loRaWAN hotspots + 5G hotspots + HNT holders + DC holders + Helium employees + DeWi [I thought of two more stakeholders] We need to weight each stakeholder group as to the power they should have in said governance. governance = (a * HST holders) + (b * validators) + (c * loRaWAN hotspots) + (d * 5G hotspots) + (e * HNT holders) + (f * DC holders) + (g * Helium employees) + (h * DeWi) One argument, and probably the simplest to make, would be that a, b, c, d, e, f, g, and h should be equal. Don't get hung up yet on how we confirm that a vote belongs to a specific stakeholder. Also don't hung up on determining if one member of a stakeholder group has more voting power than another member of the same stakeholder group (e.g., someone with 1 hotspot gets same vote as someone with 31 hotspots). Ask yourself the question of "whether or not every stakeholder group gets an equal say in the governance of the Helium project? Or should some stakeholder groups have more say in the governance of the Helium Project?".
01:05
. I will start the bidding on the weighting. Since this is a decentralized project, I am thinking it is probably prudent to not give "helium employees" any voting power. Their opinions are important but they shouldn't get to vote. I am also thinking about how the SEC would view this; an even bigger 'no' is what I think the SEC would say. F should be set to 0.00 While customers should generally have input, I think since data credits only exist if you burn HNT then "DC holders" can be folded into "HNT holders". I am also thinking a function to determine the relative value between DC holders would require billions of DCs of delta between them, so why bother. G should be set to 0.00 HNT holders seem to already wield a lot of say in that they are voting with their dollars and directly affect the price of the token through buying, selling, and staking. So I don't think as a group they should have even more governance power; however, we need some way for them to formally participate in governance. E should be set to 0.05 DeWi should probably have a single vote (and not each member having one). H should be set to 0.15 The other stakeholder groups should have equal say between them. A, B, C, and D should be set to 0.20 or 20% of the say in what is decided for future HIPs (and other scenarios where a vote is needed).
KeithR 10/31/2021 11:13 AM
Does silence mean no one disagrees with me? Or does it mean no one is interested and I am just talking to myself again?
KeithR
Does silence mean no one disagrees with me? Or does it mean no one is interested and I am just talking to myself again?

Unless of course you add up all the HNT that was burnt to make that DC than you could roll them into each other I guess. Now HST could be used but if HNT can also be voting power it shouldnâ€™t double dip so I agree that HST shouldnâ€™t be utilized.
KeithR 10/31/2021 1:25 PM
@Anthonyra --> Now HST could be used but if HNT can also be voting power it shouldnâ€™t double dip so I agree that HST shouldnâ€™t be utilized. So I like your point of double dipping. However, I had lowered HNT holders voting power already since we seem to all agree we don't want people buying votes. Also, HNT holders are already rewarded directly by the network and presumably their primary focus is only on raising the price of the asset. So I propose that when we calculate the relative value between HST owners, they need "more" to get relative votes to acknowledge their ability to double dip.
Anthonyra
I donâ€™t think DC holders should be folded into HNT. If the DC holder is a service provider they probably will burn all their HNT into DC to support it. Unless of course you add up all the HNT that was burnt to make that DC than you could roll them into each other I guess. Now HST could be used but if HNT can also be voting power it shouldnâ€™t double dip so I agree that HST shouldnâ€™t be utilized.
KeithR 10/31/2021 1:34 PM
I was figuring that it was financially imprudent to buy lots of DCs ahead of time; unless of course you think the price of HNT will go down between now and when you will spend the DC. If you think HNT will go up in value then you should buy HNT now and then wait until the last minute to buy DCs from your HNT inventory. If you don't want to gamble on the price of HNT, then you would mange your cash flow and only buy DCs at the very moment you need them. I was also thinking that if you were to give HNT holders and DC holders the same voting power, DC holders would need to have billions of DCs to equal what a HNT holder would have. To equal the difference between a 10 HNT holder and a 1000 HNT holder's vote power, the equivalent DC numbers at $30 would be 30,000,000 DCs and 3,000,000,000. Do you really foresee organizations actually holding 3 billion DCs? Given they are in the business of utilizing the network, they would have to have at least a neutral, if not positive, view of the price of HNT and thus the prudent course of action is to simply hold HNT.
Carl-bot BOT 10/31/2021 1:34 PM
No discussions on buying or selling HNT please!
Anthonyra 10/31/2021 1:58 PM
Iâ€™d be perfectly fine with HNT being the baseline howeverâ€¦ because I think Iâ€™m essence itâ€™s the most basic contributor to the network. The hotspots, validators, and DC users could add a tier higher to HNT
Anthonyra

15:32

Anthonyra 10/31/2021 3:47 PM
Maybe make the weight based on the number on chain? Theres more HNT on chain than hotspots. HNT staked * stake time weight * (sum of hotspots transmit scales) + (# validator * 20,000)... since validators is staked HNT for 5 months IE there's an account that has staked 100 HNT for 5 months = 100 VP but owns 100 hotspots with 1.0 transmit scales => 10,000 VP but owns a validator too => 30,000 VP (edited)
KeithR
I was figuring that it was financially imprudent to buy lots of DCs ahead of time; unless of course you think the price of HNT will go down between now and when you will spend the DC. If you think HNT will go up in value then you should buy HNT now and then wait until the last minute to buy DCs from your HNT inventory. If you don't want to gamble on the price of HNT, then you would mange your cash flow and only buy DCs at the very moment you need them. I was also thinking that if you were to give HNT holders and DC holders the same voting power, DC holders would need to have billions of DCs to equal what a HNT holder would have. To equal the difference between a 10 HNT holder and a 1000 HNT holder's vote power, the equivalent DC numbers at $30 would be 30,000,000 DCs and 3,000,000,000. Do you really foresee organizations actually holding 3 billion DCs? Given they are in the business of utilizing the network, they would have to have at least a neutral, if not positive, view of the price of HNT and thus the prudent course of action is to simply hold HNT.
Anthonyra 10/31/2021 3:54 PM
Since DC burnt is the ultimate stake I think it should be HNT burnt * 500 instead of * 50 for the max lockup..
KeithR 10/31/2021 4:00 PM
I think you are jumping ahead... The issue I am trying to solve is whether or not the group of people that own validators should have more say in the future of the project than the group of people that have hotspots. Do the group of validators have more say than the group of people that own HST? What about the group of people that are holding HNT? Mostly what I am trying to get the discussion to do is to define what are our values in governance? I think we can have an equation to determine voting power that embodies those values (and since we are using computers, complexity of the equation doesn't matter one iota).

Anthonyra 10/31/2021 4:02 PM
I think that validators are the same as someone who staked 10k HNT for 5 months. But since they offer a service to the blockchain I'm okay with 1 validator being 2x as much as someone who just staked HNT
16:06
HNT should be the base line that's multiplied by the time they stake it for. DC is the total number of HNT burnt to get that DC on the account times 500 since it's the ultimate stake length Hotspots should be a multiplier to that number based on the sum of all of the hotspots transmit scales on that account. Validators should be x2 the VP as if just staking 10k HNT for 5months to vote (edited)

KeithR 10/31/2021 9:35 PM

KeithR

Anthonyra 11/01/2021 6:50 AM
If they have the same voting power then they have the same say. Getting that voting power will depend on the voter. There is a couple of benefits going this way, mind you the HNT stake will be on the wallet itself and not delegated to an already existing validator. This opens up the ability to every stakeholder possible. It also allows different stakeholders different means to get to the VP hopefully equal to their network contribution. If someone has 10k HNT willing to be used to vote they'd be persuaded to validate instead (twice the bang for buck). If they have hotspots it'll motivate them to have a better transmit scale also providing for VP
Anthonyra

This opens up the ability to every stakeholder possible. It also allows different stakeholders different means to get to the VP hopefully equal to their network contribution. If they have hotspots it'll motivate them to have a better transmit scale also providing for VP
clendaniel 11/01/2021 7:39 AM
The problem with a lot of these more complex multipliers is that it assumes a single wallet. I'll offer myself up as an example with several wallets used regularly.....one that 'houses' my personal hotspots but regularly gets dumped into a ledger-based wallet and a third that's tied to a validator. How would this situation be allowed for without having someone like myself negatively affected vs the 'same' in a single wallet?

clendaniel 11/01/2021 11:57 AM
@KeithR Oh, I get that part and it's not what I was talking about....my question was more how the last one accommodated folks with multiple wallets. By applying the hotspot/xmit scale multiplier they'd be unable to use the full 'power' of their holdings without moving things around. Take the following person with 3 wallets: Wallet 1- 100HNT, 10 1.0 hotspots, 0 validators Wallet 2- 10k HNT, 0 hotspots, 0 validators (the ledger scenario I offered for those of us that prefer to use hw wallets for the bulk of holdings) Wallet 3- 100HNT, 0 hotspots, 1 validator With 3 separate wallets assuming a 5mo stake and the user going 'all-in' I'm interpreting @Anthonyra's equation given earlier as: Wallet 1- (100 * 10) + 0 = 1000VP Wallet 2- 10000VP Wallet 3- 100 + 20000 = 20100VP Effective total: 31100VP Whereas in a single wallet with the same assumptions it'd be: (10200 * 10) + 20000 = 122000VP See what I'm talking about? Now, keep in mind I'm just playing devil's advocate and acknowledge that if it's important enough for someone that they could (should?) move their holdings in a manner to maximize their potential voting power but by making it overly complex you're likely going to see some pissy people. It also shows a potential deficiency in that if you intend to apply a multiplier based on average xmit scaling of hotspots why wouldn't I split the 'problem children' with low scaling into a separate wallet and/or remove all of them if the total multiplier falls <1? (edited)
Anthonyra 11/01/2021 12:05 PM
I would recommend looking at how the current network looks with my suggestion of weighing. https://etl.dewi.org/question/648-vote-power?stake_hnt=100&length=250000 I also think that there should be more towards the hotspots multiplier preferably the beacon/witness ratio that'll exist after HIP42 but even as is you'll see some interesting power shifts based on account structures. However, I think it should be up to the voter to determine what is best for them and if they wanted to stake 10.2K HNT for 5 months just to vote and use the hotspot multiplier like they did that's a win-win for the network in my opinion... (edited)

KeithR 11/01/2021 4:01 PM
My response is a lousy defense; those are not my equations. I would not put all of the stakeholders into a single equation actually. I am trying to answer the question at one level of abstraction up; does each stakeholder group get the same say in the governance. I haven't even gotten to the within group differences yet. From my perspective (and the problem may potentially still exist...) I would address your scenario in the following manner; you could vote 5 times. You could vote from each wallet within the HNT holder stakeholder group. You could vote once within the hotspot owner stakeholder group. You could vote once within the validator owner stakeholder group (I think). (edited)
1
KeithR 11/01/2021 4:10 PM
I say "i think" with the validator group vote because I am not convinced just yet that just cause you staked into a validator you aren't just like a HNT holder. I am currently more thinking about the people that are running validators; in that, they know more about how the mechanisms are being done for the network and blockchain. I could be convinced HNT holders that stake to a validator are different than simply HNT holders very easily. I am thinking that the two groups are people that just bought HNT on coinbase (wishful thinking) versus you staked at Helium Rising or StakeJoy or similar. The difference being "staking". That said, Ross, owner of Helium Rising, has a different perspective as an operator of validators than me as a member of the staking pool there. And presumably I am different from someone with 1900 tokens in binance. (edited)
Carl-bot BOT 11/01/2021 4:10 PM
No discussion on exchanges here, please see #rules.
KeithR 11/01/2021 4:14 PM
The abstraction level up is whether the three of us (Ross, me, and hypothetical customer at binance) get an equal say in the governance. Do we as the different stakeholder groups get equal say but to get that say we have to commit different amounts within that stakeholder group. Ross for instance only has to be a validator operator to get 1% of his stakeholder group. I need to stake 20,000 HNT to equal his vote. And our hypothetical customer needs to buy and be holding 100,000 HNT to equal our vote. These are totally made up numbers....I am jumping ahead...we need to agree on the weighting of each stakeholder group first.
Carl-bot BOT 11/01/2021 4:14 PM

Anthonyra 11/01/2021 4:39 PM

KeithR 11/01/2021 10:15 PM
I am second guessing the validator stakeholder group and whether they should have a say in governance. Are we talking about the 20 people who run validators as a job or side hustle? Sure they have an opinion that might be unique, but can't we just get that opinion and guidance in a consultative manner, much like we get, and should only get, from Helium employees regarding any HIP? Or are we talking about the people who have 10,000 HNT (or more) and thus are economically able to stake said HNT in their own validator? Are we including the folks that have fewer than 10,000 HNT and chose to stake those tokens, with far more risk taken than the preceding group, in a validator pool? Aren't both of the latter groups of people really just HNT holders expressing more commitment via staking? So not about the validators per se; it is about the staking. Which begs the question of how much voting power do tokens not staked get versus staked. 50,000 not staked equals 10,000 staked? (edited)
22:18
Is 10,000 staked in your own validator equal to 10,000 staked at Helium Rising? Or because of the additional risk taken by participating in a pool without delegated staking as part of the token does it only take 9,100 tokens at Helium Rising to equal the say of someone with 10,000 in their own safe space, er validator. (edited)
Anthonyra 11/02/2021 6:21 AM

I think that 20,000 VP for a validator makes sense because it also incentives someone who has 10K hnt to provide a validator if they only want to lock that amount up for 5 months. When it comes to the validator pools, it's up to the poolers and the pools to determine how they will function. clendaniel 11/02/2021 7:50 AM
I'm not following on how staking via a validator pool is more of a risk and more valuable than an individual staking and running a validator independently....I'd argue there's less risk or commitment as a number of the pools will allow folks to unstake/withdraw without a cooldown period. Like @Anthonyra said the validator itself provides a service to the network and doesn't come without it's own costs and time. I can speak from personal experience that hosting costs for them can be significant and maintenance is akin to my legacy alpha DIY, it takes more than 'deploy it and let it run' that those deploying hotspots enjoy.
clendaniel
I'm not following on how staking via a validator pool is more of a risk and more valuable than an individual staking and running a validator independently....I'd argue there's less risk or commitment as a number of the pools will allow folks to unstake/withdraw without a cooldown period. Like @Anthonyra said the validator itself provides a service to the network and doesn't come without it's own costs and time. I can speak from personal experience that hosting costs for them can be significant and maintenance is akin to my legacy alpha DIY, it takes more than 'deploy it and let it run' that those deploying hotspots enjoy.
KeithR 11/02/2021 12:10 PM
The additional risk is that you are giving up your tokens to stake. So there is a non-zero chance that the validator pool gets cleaned out and all the pool members lose their stake. If we had delegated staking as Cardano has for example, then all staking would be the same safe transaction.
capcom 11/02/2021 3:29 PM
right. it's a huge risk as you give up custody of your HNT
KeithR
The additional risk is that you are giving up your tokens to stake. So there is a non-zero chance that the validator pool gets cleaned out and all the pool members lose their stake. If we had delegated staking as Cardano has for example, then all staking would be the same safe transaction.

KeithR 11/03/2021 4:12 AM
To tell you the truth, I think that is where I am at as well. Every stakeholder group gets the same say. Validators are just as important as HNT holders as important as hotspot owners. If this is the sentiment we generally all feel, then we can move on to determining the within group differences. Does an HNT holder of 5,000 tokens have 50x more say than someone with 100 tokens? I think the 5,000 token holder does have more say, but nowhere near 50x. I like some of the variables you pointed out in doing that calculation. Does someone with one validator have twice the say as someone with two validators? Does a person with a fleet of 50 hotspots have 10x more say than someone with 5 hotspots?

Anthonyra 11/04/2021 1:07 PM
The burn is also meant for those that don't have a lot to get more bang for their buck also... For example, top 100 accounts currently have 50% of all HNT
13:08
Now x500 might be a lot.. could simply be 250 or what ever number makes sense..
somejunkray 11/04/2021 1:10 PM
It's just that any multiplication is not a 1:1 voice per person vote, which historically speaking is a bad thing to give one person more voting power than another.
1
Anthonyra 11/04/2021 1:11 PM
The issue is that with a blockchain you can't do 1:1 unless you want to do KYC
somejunkray 11/04/2021 1:12 PM
Yea, it's a tricky dilemma. Can't say I have any better answers, just that this kind of feels like the wrong solution. I'll keep wracking my brain. Clearly those with more skin in the game have a vested interest, but that's only because they've had the benefit of having more or being around longer. Not necessarily that they deserve more voting power. (edited)
Anthonyra 11/04/2021 1:14 PM
However, if the concern is the burning of HNT to get x500 I think x100 would even work for the intention. For every HNT burnt the supply decreases and well that's good for everyone
somejunkray 11/04/2021 1:16 PM
Without knowing what the vote is for, it's hard to say. But those who have more can afford it. Say a small group of enthusiastic deployers who have set up an entire town or two of coverage between them (possibly by encouraging others to have their own wallet and hold a hotspot but have no interest in voting, so they dont get the multiplier value) vs someone with an ungodly amount of tokens who can just burn 1000 like it's nobodies business.
Anthonyra 11/04/2021 1:17 PM
But I'd argue that's their business, and that would only give them 1,000,000 VP which could be easily defended
somejunkray 11/04/2021 1:18 PM
Possibly... but how many miners who only have one miner, with very low earnings (.1 hnt per month or something) because they didn't invest a ton of cash and it sits in their window best they can. How many of those people would it take to offset the balance of that one big fish?
Anthonyra 11/04/2021 1:21 PM
The real voting power comes from the skin in the game
1
13:23
Sure someone could have mined a lot of HNT from being an early adopter, or maybe they had cash from selling PayPal who knows. The real question is if the vote itself is worth the skin in the game it takes to win? Hard to say like you said based on not knowing the vote. But I know for a fact the exchanges wouldn't be able to burn all their tokens. I know that most of the big investors won't be willing to burn all of their tokens. But IF the little guys see's that burning their 1-5HNT could swing the vote in the way they want it... well win win win because supply goes down, the little guy wins the vote, and Helium grows
ad3z 11/10/2021 11:13 AM
not sure if this is the right channel to discuss this:
Allowing the voters to see the current vote results in real-time is a bad approach. It will discourage votes on the weaker side, since they assume the vote result is clear.
 (edited)
baskin 11/10/2021 11:30 AM
+1 on that. Presenting the results before the closer of the vote is a childish way to do voting
1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/10/2021 8:14 PM
+1000 Showing the results while voting is going on taints the results. It's a well know issue that people are influenced to vote for the side that is winning when shown the current results.
3

Leo 11/12/2021 11:07 AM
Has anyone ever thought of governance by hotspots owned rather than by token ammounts?
1
evan 11/12/2021 11:08 AM
this channel has like 5 versions of that argument
11:08
please read the scrollback
evan
this channel has like 5 versions of that argument
Leo 11/12/2021 11:08 AM
Sorry, just arrived. Will do.
Leo 11/12/2021 11:17 AM
Read back
11:23
Here's my take: The ammount of HNT a wallet owns should have no impact on governance. People shouldn't have a say because they have money. They should have a say because they actively participate in the growth and maintence of the network. Both Hotspot Owners and Validators should have the capacity to vote. I'd suggest a method to reduce the voting power of massive hotspot owners (50 or 100 +), to make the vote as democratic as possible. One of the biggest governance issues of most blockchain projects is that the network doesn't belong to the people, it belongs to the very rich; what happened to steem is a perfect example of it. We have a way to not go down that road, and that is by giving the votes not to the rich, but to the actual actors of this network.
evan 11/12/2021 11:31 AM
the problem here is that most hotspots are owned by the very rich too
Leo
Here's my take: The ammount of HNT a wallet owns should have no impact on governance. People shouldn't have a say because they have money. They should have a say because they actively participate in the growth and maintence of the network. Both Hotspot Owners and Validators should have the capacity to vote. I'd suggest a method to reduce the voting power of massive hotspot owners (50 or 100 +), to make the vote as democratic as possible. One of the biggest governance issues of most blockchain projects is that the network doesn't belong to the people, it belongs to the very rich; what happened to steem is a perfect example of it. We have a way to not go down that road, and that is by giving the votes not to the rich, but to the actual actors of this network.

Leo 11/12/2021 1:16 PM
Because like what happened with steem, actors with high voting power have the capacity to subvert the system in their favour.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/12/2021 1:16 PM
All you have said is you want to limit large fleet voting. No method
13:16
So what is your method?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
So what is your method?
Leo 11/12/2021 1:21 PM
Accounts with over 2 hotspot get ehir voting power per hotspot proportionally reduced to the ammount of hotspots they have. So lets say you have one hotspot, you'll have 1 VP. 2 hotspots, 1.5 VP. 3 hotspots, 1.75 VP. Etc etc etc. People with high ammounts of hotspots will never distribute them per account, because that will incur in transaction costs the ammount of times they distributed their hospots. So, if someone with 600 hotspots creates 600 addresses, they'll pay 600x more transaction fees, 600x the ammount of HNT burned to vote, etc etc. Its inneficient for their voting model. Also, this can also be mitigated by making it so you can exclusively vote via the app, so you'd have to login 600 times to do those 600 votes (edited)
1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/12/2021 1:21 PM
hmm... so a VP decay. Interesting
Leo 11/12/2021 1:21 PM
You can even go as far as to actually reduce the vote to 1 per address if you are able to limit voting to the app. (edited)
Leo
Accounts with over 2 hotspot get ehir voting power per hotspot proportionally reduced to the ammount of hotspots they have. So lets say you have one hotspot, you'll have 1 VP. 2 hotspots, 1.5 VP. 3 hotspots, 1.75 VP. Etc etc etc. People with high ammounts of hotspots will never distribute them per account, because that will incur in transaction costs the ammount of times they distributed their hospots. So, if someone with 600 hotspots creates 600 addresses, they'll pay 600x more transaction fees, 600x the ammount of HNT burned to vote, etc etc. Its inneficient for their voting model. Also, this can also be mitigated by making it so you can exclusively vote via the app, so you'd have to login 600 times to do those 600 votes (edited)

1
alphamethod 11/13/2021 10:48 AM
What if we did zero knowledge KYC aka verified credentials. Pretty common concept in decentralized identity circles. It's where you can verify that someone is a unique individual without knowing what the underlying mechanism of verification was. Just that it was verified by an authoritative source. So each verified individual has a single vote, and then weight the vote to a certain degree based on the amount of HNT you hold.
10:51
I do agree that voting right now is quite disproportionately skewed to people with large amounts of HNT. Not that they shouldn't have more weight to their vote, but maybe it shouldn't be linearly proportional to the amount of HNT they have.
10:55
If you wanna get fancy, then maybe certain attributes can "garnish" an account with more weight. Aka verified hotspot owners, verified to be running validators, verified to have contributed to marketing, etc etc. Some can be verified on chain and then certain accounts can be issued verified credentials that affect their vote weight. Other, less tangible credentials could potentially be distributed by something like a committee.

Youâ€™re making your HNT not liquid anymore.h (edited)

Start at a baseline, add multipliers and factors to groups that provide more to the network than others.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/14/2021 12:18 PM

KeithR 11/14/2021 3:05 PM
I am sure I am being pedantic, but I don't think what you guys are talking about is a decay function. "Decay" is something that diminishes over time. What we are after, and you and I have already talked about this, is a diminishing returns model for any of these things that the rich have advantages simply because they are wealthy. Ownership of hotspots, ownership of HNT, or time available for token lock. More hotspots is valuable to the network and thus should get you more voting power, but at some point you are simply benefiting from your wealth. So something like 5x for every additional hotspot in your wallet up to 100 hotspots, then 3x for the 101st hotspot up to 300 hotspots, then 2x from 301st hotspot up to 500 hotspots, and then simply 1x more for 501 hotspots and above. A similar diminishing returns model can be applied to amount of HNT and the benefit of token lock. (edited)
KeithR
I am sure I am being pedantic, but I don't think what you guys are talking about is a decay function. "Decay" is something that diminishes over time. What we are after, and you and I have already talked about this, is a diminishing returns model for any of these things that the rich have advantages simply because they are wealthy. Ownership of hotspots, ownership of HNT, or time available for token lock. More hotspots is valuable to the network and thus should get you more voting power, but at some point you are simply benefiting from your wealth. So something like 5x for every additional hotspot in your wallet up to 100 hotspots, then 3x for the 101st hotspot up to 300 hotspots, then 2x from 301st hotspot up to 500 hotspots, and then simply 1x more for 501 hotspots and above. A similar diminishing returns model can be applied to amount of HNT and the benefit of token lock. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/14/2021 3:06 PM
Pretty sure we're talking the same thing. :)
15:07
Same as the "decay" function in hip44
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Those that built the network have ownership, and thus have the right to vote. Customers didn't build anything.
KeithR 11/14/2021 3:11 PM
I agree with you on this normally. However, since this is a decentralized project, really no one owns anything in the project. [now interestingly, we do own the physical manifestations of the network; the hotspots)]. Validators don't own the software they are running. Most of them don't own the machines they are running them on. I don't own the hotspots that I actually make more money off (the ones I witness). Helium doesn't own the hotspots and as a result doesn't really own the service being provided. Kind of weird if you think about it. So I really think everyone has a say in the governance of this thing. What we need to settle on is how much say do they have and how much more say do we allow them to get with their wealth. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Same as the "decay" function in hip44
KeithR 11/14/2021 3:12 PM
I agree that we seem to be trying to paint the same picture. My problem is with using "decay" to describe something that doesn't use time as its variable. (edited)

What we are after, and you and I have already talked about this, is a diminishing returns model for any of these things that the rich have advantages simply because they are wealthy. Ownership of hotspots, ownership of HNT, or time available for token lock. More hotspots is valuable to the network and thus should get you more voting power, but at some point you are simply benefiting from your wealth. A similar diminishing returns model can be applied to amount of HNT and the benefit of token lock. (edited)

Deleted User 11/14/2021 3:29 PM
This is interesting but not impossible to overcome either. Now consider if Alice (owner of 500 hotspots) decides to ask her five friends - Mary, Bob, Joe, Doug and Erin to become wallet owners to satisfy KYC requirements in exchange for x amount of money while retaining physical control of those wallets, she could still effectively have control of the voting power it just becomes a tiny bit more painful at the cost of more effort and money. I think it comes down to how badly they want to sway the vote, the means to do needs to become far more difficult where they don't even want to attempt it. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Oof... Yeah

Validators should vote I think. Yes they are rewarded for their work just like hotspots are, but they are a functional part of the network. I was thinking that their voting power would be scaled on some factor long the lines of the % of consensus groups they are involved with, so that poorly performing validators are scaled just like poorly placed hotspots.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/14/2021 5:24 PM
That is the inherent downside of voting: Can't filter your voters
17:25
Best you can do is educate best as possible.
CrunchBang';-- 11/14/2021 5:28 PM
or come up with a better chant As a newcomer with no real context for this, the idea of votes scaling with holdings of coin seems terrible. You can then buy influence in the network at a nearly limitless scale. Votes based on synced hotspots seems much more sensible.

Leo 11/14/2021 5:54 PM
at this point you can just make a giga aggressive system where each wallet can only have 1 vote. If they aren't doing it for a decay system, they are doing it for a 1 vote per wallet system either
17:57
IMO, it should be: 1 vote per wallet with at least: 1 Hotspot OR 1 Validator; 1 vote per user that consumes over (X) ammount of DC. Hotspot owners, Validators and network users are the 3 main parties that make this network work. These are the 3 main participators, and all 3 should get one vote alone.
18:00
I originally proposed the decay system; It's downfall was that companies like Emrit, FairSpot, and others could spread their hotspots over several wallets, subverting the system. But if this is considered in a decay system, there's no reason not take a step ahead and make it so each wallet can only have one vote, no matter how many hotspots they have. no decay system. 1 vote. As close to a democracy we can get.
Leo

Leo 11/14/2021 6:31 PM
my definition of it is: is it necessary for the network to run? if so, it runs the network. The expression might be off, but i hope i've explained myself with this
Leo
btw question @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped : In your view, what is the actual downside of having DC users vote?

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/14/2021 6:38 PM
Is there any utility that allows customers to vote on functional operations and policies?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Is there any utility that allows customers to vote on functional operations and policies?
Leo 11/14/2021 6:40 PM
Of course! Besides actually being able to give the customer a vote, which is a morally and ethically sound thing to do, it's a great selling point to have people join the network: Letting them have a voice within it, participate in how it changes and evolves will give potential customer companies a big positive signal. One of the things customers seek the most is the ability to give feedback and improve the product they are using. This is the perfect way to do it.
Leo

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/19/2021 12:36 PM
@Leo
It suffers from the same problem as the 1 vote 1 wallet. Big actors can always just separate their hotspots by multiple wallets. 1 vote 1 wallet makes this harder, more costly, and more time consuming, since the ideal would be to make it so you have to forcefully vote with the app. Imagine manually voting 600 times.
Yes, it all works together. App voting and "decay"

KeithR 11/19/2021 2:20 PM
Of course. But I already laid out what i thought was ideal with @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped a week ago. One 1 hotspot = 1 vote with a diminishing returns penalty to adversely affect super large fleets. Yes I know the wealthy can then move each hotspot to a separate wallet to avoid the diminishing returns algorithm. That is where his suggestion of forcing the vote to be placed in the app settles it for me. If they want to put that much effort in skirting the ideals of voting then let them. If folks want to add in transmit scale, I am fine with it; won't argue for it but won't argue against it either. (edited)
1
KeithR

Yes I know the wealthy can then move each hotspot to a separate wallet to avoid the diminishing returns algorithm. That is where his suggestion of forcing the vote to be placed in the app settles it for me. If they want to put that much effort in skirting the ideals of voting then let them. If folks want to add in transmit scale, I am fine with it; won't argue for it but won't argue against it either. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/19/2021 3:50 PM
Do you have an issue/thoughts on the transmit scale part?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Do you have an issue/thoughts on the transmit scale part?
KeithR 11/19/2021 3:56 PM
The reason I wouldn't fight for it is due to my perception that it is a simplistic method of pushing where we want locations and thus doesn't warrant influencing voting power. That is, it is just counts of hotspots in a fixed amount of land area. So while I think it is beautiful idea as a method of pushing hotspots toward the under-served areas, I just don't think it is complex enough. Population is not considered for instance. Natural barriers to coverage are not considered (elevated highways, building height, building material, etc). Self report of assertion. Actual coverage measuring (I understand this is probably impossible, but I have one idea...a KYH approach).
1
1
KeithR
The reason I wouldn't fight for it is due to my perception that it is a simplistic method of pushing where we want locations and thus doesn't warrant influencing voting power. That is, it is just counts of hotspots in a fixed amount of land area. So while I think it is beautiful idea as a method of pushing hotspots toward the under-served areas, I just don't think it is complex enough. Population is not considered for instance. Natural barriers to coverage are not considered (elevated highways, building height, building material, etc). Self report of assertion. Actual coverage measuring (I understand this is probably impossible, but I have one idea...a KYH approach).
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/19/2021 4:00 PM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped

KeithR 11/19/2021 4:01 PM

KeithR 11/19/2021 4:13 PM
My hex has like 25 households in it. My helium buddy's hex has 200 households. Just adding that data to the transmit scale algorithm would make for a better proxy of the usefulness of each hotspot in that hex. My one hotspot has my hex more than covered; arguably I am good enough for three other hexes near me as well. And after I put my hotspot up in one of my 140' trees, I might cover about 6 more hexes, reliably. My buddy's hotspot coverage is being attenutated by any one of the several condo complexes around him. His hex definitely benefits from extra hotspots to find the dog that is running loose down the alley. Population per hex would add to the quality of the transmit scale calculation. Don't get me started with all of the disambiguation data that is out there for all the bridges, signs, buildings, blah, blah. Imagine if you added all that data in there. (edited)

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 11/19/2021 4:19 PM
I think they were going for a idealized coverage map. Counting "area covered" as the "useful" part, rather than figuring the actual devices being serviced. They likely figured that the real usefulness will be shown in DC collected by those hotspots. We're in just a weird spot right now where PoC the the vast majority of rewards. Once DC is the driving force behind rewards, the scaling thing will mostly be a moot point.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped

AndrewsMD 11/20/2021 5:08 AM
I read HIP41 for the first time in itâ€™s entirety and I applaud its intention. I havenâ€™t been participating in this channel until now. So in advance, please forgive my ignorance and feel free to educate me as I seek to learn more. Regarding the Commit and Reveal section. Assume wallet owner Leon (made up name) seeks to steer the voting result in a particular way and game the voting system. Also assume, in this example, that the direction Leon wants to go has a negative impact on the network as a whole. What is to stop Leon, from opening more than one wallet, place a minimal amount of HNT in several wallets so that he can â€œrevealâ€ the vote progress at several stages? For Leon plans to use a larger voting power wallet at the 9th hour so that he can skew results in his favor? Also, Leon, a closed minded individual who always believes he is right despite evidence to the contrary, will stop at nothing to get the voting to go his way. He will even post his low cost reveal to social media to spread fear and drum up uninformed support in favor of his position. Is there a plan in place to mitigate risks against voting integrity issues as described above? Did I miss something relevant in the HIP41?
AndrewsMD

What is to stop Leon, from opening more than one wallet, place a minimal amount of HNT in several wallets so that he can â€œrevealâ€ the vote progress at several stages? For Leon plans to use a larger voting power wallet at the 9th hour so that he can skew results in his favor? Also, Leon, a closed minded individual who always believes he is right despite evidence to the contrary, will stop at nothing to get the voting to go his way. keith 11/21/2021 5:33 AM
Until HIP39 we had no real voting mechanism and the security token holders along with Helium Inc were 100% in control of all chain variable changes (I would not consider the discord votes true votes). If anything this new structure implemented with HIP39 is a more 'fair' system as it gives the rest of the community the ability to vote. I think the burn vs lock idea has potential but I do not see a reason to take away the relationship between HNT ownership and vote weight since HNT is the defacto measure of ownership/investment in the network.
AndrewsMD 11/21/2021 8:30 AM
I agree with this statement. There is merit to the intention of HIP41, but there may be flaws in its design. I havenâ€™t figured out how to resolve them yet. There is no 100% best voting system in place. I havenâ€™t made my final decision yet regarding this HIP, but in its current form, Iâ€™m not certain that I am in favor. Could it be modified to win my vote? Of course this is possible. I need to read it again, this time more carefully. And I will. However, on a fundamental & philosophical level, I take issue with it especially if it has the risk of having the opposite desired effect. A community is stronger when people are encouraged to vote and not be penalized for it (if locking their HNT is penalizing in their perception). For example, those with larger balances of HNT not only have an existing vote power that is larger than someone who has a smaller balance, they also, theoretically, have more staying power. Thus, theoretically have more power/ability to stake/lock their HNT. Consider a prominent venture capital group who reportedly put up over $100 million towards Heliumâ€™s network. They would have no issue locking their HNT vote for a prolonged period of time to ensure the growth of this network and the success of their investment. Therefore, did this HIP41 accomplish its underlying intent to wrest voting control from those who have invested much into the hands of those who have invested little? Will people with smaller balances think the voting is too complex and therefore, the juice isnâ€™t worth the squeeze? Are there changes or improvements to the existing voting system that would be simpler?
08:30
HIP39 demonstrated that we can disagree with each other, listen to each otherâ€™s arguments and get people to vote their opinions. It was a remarkable feat of getting people engaged in the latest hip vote. Going forward I predict more people will vote. We need a system that is easy and understandable, not convoluted in an effort to increase oneâ€™s voting power. In my opinion, being vested in the company coupled with an incentive to make decisions that benefit the community can be measured best by length of time in the community, and the dollar amount vested through growing the network (I.e., put your money where your mouth is concept). The unit of measurement of â€œbeing vestedâ€ with time and money into the welfare of the community should be as it stands today, . . . amount of HNT. The very premise of being a validator currently requires 10,000 HNT. Should that change too???

The whole community could vote before, 1 person 1 vote. Now, 5 people control the whole voting process. Hnt ownership os not s measure of ownership/investment on the network. Hotspots and validators are.

keith 11/21/2021 11:15 AM
Yes you can buy large portions of corporations, it happens all the time. You could have dumped millions into HNT purchases if you wanted to make your say worth more. You are correct it is the â€˜peoplesâ€™ network but for the first 20 years the security token holders have a deserved higher say in the future of the network due to their initial investment (in HNT). Holding HNT does not hinder the growth it lowers liquidity pushing the price up which in turn returns more value to hotspot owners (and therefore speeds ROI) Higher potential returns drive growth. Also, HNT has a fixed cap, hotspots does not, do you want 3% of your voting power next year as you had this year because that is exactly what happened over the last 24 months (and HNT earnings dropped along with it). Why would I buy more hotspots if my vote just continues to get diluted (see why stock prices go down when companies issue more shares)? HNT as shares to vote makes the most sense as it is the most stable and traceable metric to tie votes to just as shares in corporations have used stock for thousands of years.

AndrewsMD 11/21/2021 7:56 PM
The logic regarding the motivation of this HIP41 as described in the second paragraph escapes me. Can the author of this HIP explain this to me in a meaningful way? Here is what the hip says in the second paragraph. [â€¦] â€œThis [existing vote mechanism] is vulnerable to adversarial parties borrowing tokens for the solely for the duration of a given vote, and steering the network in a potentially harmful direction. With historical precedent of low voter turnout and low interest rates for short-term loans, this is an easily feasible attack vector.â€ After reading this my first response is, â€œwait, . . . What did I just read???â€ Assume the owner of wallet â€œXâ€ desires to â€œattackâ€ a particular HIP for personal/political reasons. Also assume that the amount of â€œextra vote powerâ€ from an individual that is material enough to move a voting needle in a meaningful way is equivalent to 1 million HNT if we use the most recent voting experience of HIP39 as an example. Also assume that the price of HNT is $50 during this period . The owner of wallet â€œXâ€ must effectively borrow $50 million dollars using a low interest short term loan to purchase 1 million HNT to boost their vote power in support of their desired HIP. (edited)
19:56
First of all, they may not be able to buy that much HNT at that price, because market conditions could change with a public purchase of 1 million HNT. In fact, it is foreseeable that the price to secure 1 million extra HNT may far exceed $50 million dollars plus interest, plus bank origination fees. Secondly, if it is indeed â€œshort termâ€, the owner of wallet â€œXâ€ is not guaranteed to sell said HNT at or above their purchase price in order to repay the loan. Therefore, the cost of this potential â€œattackâ€ could get quit costly and it could have a high probability of leading to a loss given its â€œshort termâ€ nature. Secondly, prior to a career in medicine, I was a Vice President of a prominent bank in charge of commercial lending. I can assure you that based on years of experience, banks donâ€™t fund this kinda stuff. Such a borrower, would have to have a prior line of credit in said amount for purposes other than that which is stated in this HIP41. From a former bankerâ€™s perspective, this doesnâ€™t even make sense. What am I missing? Who does this? I mean really??? Most borrowers who have the capacity to secure such a loan are much more financially savvy than this. When they borrow funds, . . . they make more money with said funds. Next, consider an example that has less vote power than 1 million HNT. Assume wallet owner â€œYâ€ desires to put up his home as collateral in order to secure extra funds to purchase HNT in order to steer a potential vote in a particular way. As a former banker, I would advise against this course of action, but hey, if a person has the equity available in their home, if they have the credit and cash flow to back it up, and if they are committed enough on a particular HIP to steer it one way or another, . . . YOLO, . . . I guess. More power to you. In the end, it wonâ€™t likely matter with respect to the vote when thousands of people weigh in with their un-levered positions. (edited)
19:57
Since this is one of the premises that this HIP seeks to correct, can the author of this HIP please explain the thoughts behind this? I genuinely want to know.
Leo
I dont need to. HNT aren't shares. And the US IRS isn't the world's decider of what a share is. A share means partisl ownership. If you buy HNT, what do you own? Just the HNT. A part of the total HNT supply. Issue is, HNT supply is not the network. The network is composed of hotspots and validators.
KeithR 11/21/2021 9:09 PM

KeithR 11/21/2021 9:30 PM
Try this metaphor (it is kind of what ElonTusk has said before); the network is the â€œemployerâ€ and anyone that works for the network gets a vote (â€œemployeesâ€). Hotspots work for the network and get paid in HNT for their work. Validators are workers too in this metaphor (so I guess I should support their right to vote see my previous comments for explanation). Sounds like it would be reasonable to say now that Routers are workers that arguably should get paid as well. Rat traps and sensors are customers; no vote is expected. Buyers of the currency shouldnt get a vote because they dont work for the network. Holders of HNT are either about to be customers (by burning to DCs) or to find the next fool to pay more for the utility token (borrowing from the shitcoin metaphor for Leoâ€™s sake). (edited)
21:31

21:34

1
21:39
I personally do want to add a slight socialist view to the governance. That is, a diminishing returns model. Owning 1000 hotspots shouldnt get you 1000 votes. It should get you 800 votes for instance. Owning 10 validators should get you 8 votes. Unfortunately yes there is a work around of putting 100 hotspots per wallet (or wherever the diminishing returns algo kicks in) and voting multiple times. Sure, knock your socks off if you want to be a dick. Weâ€™ll figure out ways to increase the cost of such dickishness; for instance, you must vote manually in the app. (edited)

KeithR 11/21/2021 9:47 PM

1
KeithR
Try this metaphor (it is kind of what ElonTusk has said before); the network is the â€œemployerâ€ and anyone that works for the network gets a vote (â€œemployeesâ€). Hotspots work for the network and get paid in HNT for their work. Validators are workers too in this metaphor (so I guess I should support their right to vote see my previous comments for explanation). Sounds like it would be reasonable to say now that Routers are workers that arguably should get paid as well. Rat traps and sensors are customers; no vote is expected. Buyers of the currency shouldnt get a vote because they dont work for the network. Holders of HNT are either about to be customers (by burning to DCs) or to find the next fool to pay more for the utility token (borrowing from the shitcoin metaphor for Leoâ€™s sake). (edited)
Leo 11/21/2021 10:12 PM
I like the train analogy. It's actually quite good; hotspot owners, validators, etc are train owners. Their combined ownership of said trains forms a network of trains. These trains transport people (data). Said transport ticket (DC) is bought using money (HNT). The owners of the network are the collective of train owners. HNT holders arent owners. (edited)
1
1
22:13
In practice, HNT=X ammount of USD. It's nothing beyond that
Tushar
I think HNT means network ownership and hotspots/validators are network operators. Hotspots and validators get paid in network ownership tokens (aka HNT) for doing work for the network

AndrewsMD 11/22/2021 4:00 AM
Paragraph 3 & 4 of HIP41 â€œOne-token, one vote also concentrates voting power in the hands of large market makers and traders who hold tokens for trading purposes but do not have long term commitment to the network. This can lead to smaller holders becoming disenfranchised and disengaged from governanceâ€ Wouldnâ€™t individuals who hold large amounts of HNT â€œfor trading purposesâ€ hold their HNT in an exchange instead of a ledger wallet or helium wallet? That way they can rapidly â€œsell high and buy the dipâ€. If a person is actively trading crypto, their crypto needs to be readily available to take advantage of fast paced market conditions. Storing HNT in a ledger wallet or a Helium wallet, in this scenario, is counterproductive for a short term trader. Iâ€™m having difficulty understanding the rationale of this paragraph. Will the author of this help educate me?
04:01
In paragraph 4 of HIP41, the following is quoted. â€œThis proposal outlines a system that imposes a cost on voting such that only committed participants are willing to vote.â€ Why impose a cost of voting that is greater than the cost put forth in HIP39? The cost was limited to 35 cents, this is less than the cost of a current postage stamp. Increasing the barrier to vote entry is counter productive when the objective is to have a fair vote amongst those those who have varied amounts of investment. A person who owns one hotspot with only 100 HNT in their HNT wallet is indeed committed for they are the backbone of this network. This person deserves the right to vote without absorbent costs provided that they render an informed opinion. We should be moving forward in our voting process, . . . Not backwards.
