Tushar 11/22/2021 7:07 AM
A few thoughts. First and most importantly, I don't think you are picking a fight with me and you seem to be engaging in respectful conversations as far as I can tell
1
07:08
I don't have time to write a short and concise explanation so I will have to provide a longer stream of consciousness to answer your question
07:08
The most important thing for a voting system is to be secure. Nothing else matters if the system is not secure
07:10
The only sybil resistant thing we have in the Helium network is HNT. We know that things like challenges, witnesses, and other network activity is not a sybil resistant quantity because we see hotspots spoofing those things
07:11
Number of hotspots is also only sybil resistant because of the HNT burn to onboard a hotspot. Other than that onboarding fee paid in HNT, there is nothing stopping a rouge manufacturer from creating many virtual hotspots for free
07:11
Forcing people to vote through the app is not a reasonable security model because the blockchain has no way to know whether you voted from the app manually or simulated that action by writing a script (edited)
07:13
If we agree that the most important thing for a voting system is to be secure, then I think any alternative governance proposals need to be focused on voting security first and foremost
07:16
I am happy to read and comment on any alternative governance HIPs, I would encourage the community to formally propose some ideas. I'd recommend being prepared to address voting security concerns in the HIP and in the discussion. The system needs to be secure against knowledgeable and technically sophisticated hackers
Tushar
If we agree that the most important thing for a voting system is to be secure, then I think any alternative governance proposals need to be focused on voting security first and foremost
Leo 11/22/2021 9:27 AM
That's 100% fair. I'll start to focus more on those issues
Tushar
I am happy to read and comment on any alternative governance HIPs, I would encourage the community to formally propose some ideas. I'd recommend being prepared to address voting security concerns in the HIP and in the discussion. The system needs to be secure against knowledgeable and technically sophisticated hackers
Leo 11/22/2021 9:35 AM
Would you agree that the following system would solve the problems you lifted above?- Wallets can only vote with hotspots after they've been active for 2 weeks; Using the DeWi's powers to discipline and prevent manufacturers from using their keys to produce high ammounts of virtual hotspots to effectively create votes; Having a 1 week audit period to verify there were no attacks; If an attack is detected, the referendum on said HIP is redone, with the DeWi applying appropriate action against the manufacturer.
Tushar 11/22/2021 9:36 AM
that structure gives DeWi too much power and I think the point of this HIP is to reduce DeWi's power
Tushar
that structure gives DeWi too much power and I think the point of this HIP is to reduce DeWi's power
Leo 11/22/2021 9:38 AM
The DeWi already has the power over krys anyway, correct? They are already punishing and verifying manufacturer gambling. Wouldn't this be considered s form of gambling anyway?
09:39
Can a manufacturer create hundreds if not thousands of virtual hotspots without consequences?
AndrewsMD 11/22/2021 9:48 AM
After careful evaluation of this HIP41, I donâ€™t support it in its current form. Although the idea of seeking to improve informed and committed voter turnout has merit, this HIP41 should not be approved for the following reasons: -) The high barrier to voting entry may penalize the smaller investor and at the same time reward the larger investor who has more staying power. -) The motivations behind this HIP41 are unclear at best and materially concerning regarding the health of the network. -) It doesnâ€™t accomplish its goals, but rather quite the opposite. -) It makes an already simple voting process more complex. This is a step backwards. -) The current 1 HNT = 1 vote power is an effective and fair measure of â€œskin in the gameâ€. No change in this regard is needed. (edited)
09:49
An improvement in the existing voting process would be a predetermined formalized means by which a HIP is voted on. For example, when the authors of a hip feel that their HIPxyz is ready to be presented for a potential general vote, community members should be allowed to vote one of three options. 1) This HIPxyz should be presented to the general public for a formal vote. 2) This HIPxyz should not be presented to the general public for a formal vote. 3) In its current form, this HIPxyz needs to be revised before proceeding to a general vote. In the above example, a simple majority vote would rule. However, so as not to mire and bog down the HIP process with ideas which do not positively contribute to network growth/health, HIP writers who received a majority vote of â€œmore work is neededâ€ would have an aggregate of 3 chances to present their authored HIP for voting consideration. If a writer has thrice received a â€œmore work is needed before proceeding voteâ€, then that/those specific author(s) are prevented from resubmitting that particular HIP in the future. If an alternative author feels that there is sufficient merit to the HIP, then he/she may author the HIP. These are just general thoughts to get creative juices flowing. (edited)
1
Tushar
that structure gives DeWi too much power and I think the point of this HIP is to reduce DeWi's power
AndrewsMD 11/22/2021 9:58 AM
Stating it simply, HIP41 is contentious. If there is merit to considering HIP41 further, in its current form, it would need a solid vote of approval to proceed further. Much like the voting process exemplified in HIP39. (edited)

Satchel 11/28/2021 5:43 PM

keith
No HNT no DC. You have to burn HNT to create DC. Itâ€™s a fundamental function of the network. You earn HNT as a hotspot owner. If you hold onto it one would consider that continued investment (ownership) in the network vs just selling and walking away. Holding on to HNT reduces liquidity supporting its value and promoting growth of miners to earn more HNT. And round and round we go. I have wasted enough time trying to explain markets and ownership structure.
Satchel 11/28/2021 5:45 PM
Whose HNT gets burnt when creating DC? Miners hold some, exchange buyers hold some, but is there a circulating pool of HNT that gets burned and where is that? My understanding is that this mechanism along with emissions should keep an equilibrium and tie DC credit creation volume to the exchange price of HNT: the more DC credits created the higher the effective price of HNT relative to number of DC.
keith 11/28/2021 5:48 PM
Any HNT can be burned to create DC.

Drizznarte 01/06/2022 3:33 PM
IMO Hip 39 is a good example of a poor voting system ." One token, one vote also concentrates voting power in the hands of whales and early miners. This can lead to smaller holders becoming disenfranchised and disengaging themselves from governance - which would lead to a stagnant protocol operating primarily in the interests of large/early holders. " .I definatly felt disenfranchised by this proposal that to me should of first have a vote to acertain the validitiy of the HIP itself. HIP 39 also seemed to be pushed into a vote too soon . I dont agree that the changes of HIP 41 are a good soloution as it stands , I do agree with the Commit-and-Reveal Transparency is very important in voting systems to reinforce the fundermentals . I would rater see a change to the voting system that involved a better back end analysis rather than just a percentage for or against ,answer. Also a post vote analysis that is open source so that everybody can see what size entities voted for what outcomes .In a non dox way of course. This will lead to better confidence in the system and encourage voting ! (edited)
Drizznarte 01/06/2022 3:41 PM
The motivation behind this hip41 i do agree with but the Vote Power by Lock i think is too extreme. i would prefer to see a more layed / tierd methord that required more than one vote to be held .Say have two votes .First to verify its had suitable discussion and all aspects of the hip have been discused that includes a feedback section for the people who voted before a final Vote to impliment. (edited)

Ih8mypp 02/21/2022 9:18 AM
What would the issue be with a 'one asset one vote' system, where an asset is a miner (and maybe a validator)
Ih8mypp
What would the issue be with a 'one asset one vote' system, where an asset is a miner (and maybe a validator)
KeithR 02/21/2022 9:46 AM
That the wealthy can buy a bunch of those just like they can buy a bunch of HNT and as a result have disparate voting power. The only way is KYC so that we can do â€œone person = one voteâ€. But since this is a trust less permission less system, it is an untenable option.
Ih8mypp 02/21/2022 9:48 AM
Its way way easier to buy a bunch of HNT than it is to buy devices
1
KeithR
That the wealthy can buy a bunch of those just like they can buy a bunch of HNT and as a result have disparate voting power. The only way is KYC so that we can do â€œone person = one voteâ€. But since this is a trust less permission less system, it is an untenable option.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/21/2022 5:34 PM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/21/2022 5:49 PM
Thinking more, I think the core metric should be: What is functionally required for the network to function. Hotspots - Yes. They are required to collect the data from the IoT devices. Validators - Yes. They are required for validating the various actions of the Hotspots. HNT tokens - No. The network would still function without them. Would everyone be working for free? Sure, but it's not required to make the network actually function. You could replace HNT with jellybeans and the data would still flow.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Thinking more, I think the core metric should be: What is functionally required for the network to function. Hotspots - Yes. They are required to collect the data from the IoT devices. Validators - Yes. They are required for validating the various actions of the Hotspots. HNT tokens - No. The network would still function without them. Would everyone be working for free? Sure, but it's not required to make the network actually function. You could replace HNT with jellybeans and the data would still flow.
Anthonyra 02/22/2022 11:44 AM
I understand where you're going with this, but unless your jellybeans can be converted to DC this isn't the case. I think HNT plays a part in the network but not nearly as much as DC (more so on DC usage) or the hardware side of things. It's just an easier proxy to use as of today. (edited)
Anthonyra
I understand where you're going with this, but unless your jellybeans can be converted to DC this isn't the case. I think HNT plays a part in the network but not nearly as much as DC (more so on DC usage) or the hardware side of things. It's just an easier proxy to use as of today. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/22/2022 11:56 AM
DC isn't required either. That's just again, paying for labor. Compensation for labor is not required for work to be done.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
DC isn't required either. That's just again, paying for labor. Compensation for labor is not required for work to be done.
krby 02/22/2022 1:19 PM
In theory or in practice?
krby
In theory or in practice?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/22/2022 1:22 PM
Both. Payment is not required to have the system function.
krby 02/22/2022 1:28 PM
I think that is narrowly true, but in practice I think many of us believe a few things would happen without payments: - Over use. If it costs nothing to use, data users are incentivized to use a ton of it - Decaying coverage and validation. I (and I suspect others) will not continue pay a >$100 monthly fee to service provided run a validator just for fun. I have a couple of hosts who won't let me continue to host in those locations without payment of some sort. Basically, anywhere the fiat currency is required to run some portion of the network will suffer if there is no compensation. I'm not getting into expectation of upside, I'm just talking about covering costs in fiat currency because of outside-the-chain actors.
13:29
So, while you are correct, I think it's a reasonable thing to say that the network would be much smaller without some way to compensate in (what can eventually be) fiat currency. People did it originally (when HNT was not listed) with an hope/dream of at least recouping costs.
krby
I think that is narrowly true, but in practice I think many of us believe a few things would happen without payments: - Over use. If it costs nothing to use, data users are incentivized to use a ton of it - Decaying coverage and validation. I (and I suspect others) will not continue pay a >$100 monthly fee to service provided run a validator just for fun. I have a couple of hosts who won't let me continue to host in those locations without payment of some sort. Basically, anywhere the fiat currency is required to run some portion of the network will suffer if there is no compensation. I'm not getting into expectation of upside, I'm just talking about covering costs in fiat currency because of outside-the-chain actors.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/22/2022 2:12 PM

krby 02/22/2022 2:12 PM
@groot (trying to channel @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped here because I believe it's important to know a thing well that I say I disagree with): I think ElonTusk is starting from: "vote-by-HNT is too easy to game in an election. The path from currency to voting power is super low effort". I think a one-person-one-vote mechanism (voting power requires buying others votes or perfect robotic clones) would make him happy, but without some central KYC, that doesn't work, and "central KYC" and blockchain projects are not easy things to mix So, ET is proposing a method that raises the effort required to gain more voting power AND trying to align that effort with things the network wants/needs. That's my mental model, at least. (edited)
1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/22/2022 2:14 PM
Yes, if we had KYC, this would all be moot. Without that, trying to find the next best thing.
14:15
All the rewards we get from the network are tied to our work/efforts for the network. I think that voting rights/power should be similar. HNT would totally work if it wasn't for the fact that you can just buy it with no work to grow or make the network function. (edited)
krby
@groot (trying to channel @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped here because I believe it's important to know a thing well that I say I disagree with): I think ElonTusk is starting from: "vote-by-HNT is too easy to game in an election. The path from currency to voting power is super low effort". I think a one-person-one-vote mechanism (voting power requires buying others votes or perfect robotic clones) would make him happy, but without some central KYC, that doesn't work, and "central KYC" and blockchain projects are not easy things to mix So, ET is proposing a method that raises the effort required to gain more voting power AND trying to align that effort with things the network wants/needs. That's my mental model, at least. (edited)

But as without them the network would still 'function' they don't belong to the nuts and bolts according to ET's definition (as an example). (edited)

1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 02/22/2022 2:31 PM
I have three other issues with HNT voting: 1. Seniority gives greater voting power for the same work. 2. Cheating should not be rewarded with voting power. 3. Active installers are forced to choose between using HNT to pay for growing the network vs. voting power. We should not be tying the hands of some of the most involved builders of the network.
7
1
